newsitem.title: USA: U.S., Britain, France agree to freeze Nazi gold.
newsitem.headline: U.S., Britain, France agree to freeze Nazi gold.

text.p: The United States, Britain and France have agreed to freeze the distribution of $68 million in gold bars that were looted by the Nazis from European central banks, the New York Times reported on Tuesday.
The paper said the Clinton administration believes there is new evidence to support Jewish claims that some of the gold belonged to private citizens sent to Nazi death camps.
The gold will be frozen until the evidence can be weighed, but Clinton officials think the gold could be used to create a fund to compensate Holocaust survivors.
The gold bars have been stored at the New York Federal Reserve Bank and the Bank of England, since Switzerland and Sweden turned them over to Allied powers at the end of the Second World War.
Most of the 337 metric tons of gold -- with a current value of about $4 billion -- has been returned to the European Central banks but another $68 million was to be distributed early this year.
The paper said Britain and France have agreed to hold the gold until the review is completed. Paris was to receive about a third of the $68 million.

If the European nations and the United States find that much of the stolen gold was mixed with privately owned assets, they would face the difficult talks of deciding who should receive the gold, the Times said.
"We've taken the first step, freezing the money in place," U.S. Under Secretary of Commerce Stuart Eizenstat told the paper.
